%md
# Assignment 3 - Group 43
### Jatinpreet Singh

%pyspark
# Import Libraries
from pyspark.sql.functions import col, asc
import pyspark.sql.functions as func

%md
# Read CSV files

%pyspark
ratings_df = spark.read.format("csv").option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true").load("/user/zeppelin/ratings.csv")
ratings_df.show(1)

%pyspark
books_df = spark.read.format("csv").option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true").load("/user/zeppelin/books.csv")
books_df.show(1)

%pyspark
to_read_df = spark.read.format("csv").option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true").load("/user/zeppelin/to_read.csv")
to_read_df.show(1)

%md
# Q1. What are the number of unique users and books?

msg.data: Q1. What are the number of unique users and books?

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Number of Unique Users 
ratings_df.select("user_id").distinct().count()

%pyspark
# number of  Unique Books
ratings_df.select("book_id").distinct().count()

%md 
### Unique Users: 53424
### Unique Books: 10000

%md
# Q2. What percentage of books have received the ratings 3 or less than 3?

msg.data: Q2. What percentage of books have received the ratings 3 or less than 3?

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Get minimum rating ever recieved by each book
min_rating_df = ratings_df.groupby("book_id").agg({'rating':'min'})

# Count of books who have recieved <=3 rating at least once
less_eq_three_count = min_rating_df.filter(col("min(rating)")<=3).count()

# Total unique books
total_count = float(ratings_df.select("book_id").distinct().count())

# Final percentage of books who have recieved <=3 rating
(less_eq_three_count/float(total_count))*100

%md
### All books have recieved at least one rating 3 or less. Hence, 100% of the books follow this condition.

msg.data: All books have recieved at least one rating 3 or less. Hence, 100% of the books follow this condition.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Q3. After tuning the parameters like rank, maxIter and regParam, what is the best RMSE that you have obtained?

msg.data: Q3. After tuning the parameters like rank, maxIter and regParam, what is the best RMSE that you have obtained?

paragraphs.text:
%md
### We will do hyper parameter tuning using TrainValidationSplit to select rank, maxIter and regParam. The best among all the models will be chosen for further recommendation processing.

msg.data: We will do hyper parameter tuning using TrainValidationSplit to select rank, maxIter and regParam. The best among all the models will be chosen for further recommendation processing.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Crossvalidation

from pyspark.ml.recommendation import ALS
from pyspark.sql import Row
from pyspark.ml.evaluation import RegressionEvaluator
from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegression
from pyspark.ml.tuning import ParamGridBuilder, TrainValidationSplit

# Sptilt training and test data
(training, test) = ratings_df.randomSplit([0.8, 0.2], seed = 1234)

# Create Generic ALS model - without hyperparameters
als = ALS(userCol="user_id", itemCol="book_id", ratingCol="rating", 
          nonnegative = True, # Non negative matrix factorization
          coldStartStrategy = "drop", # What to do if user do not appear in train and test set
          implicitPrefs = False) # Explicit preference

# Add hyperparameters and their respective values to param_grid
param_grid = ParamGridBuilder() \
            .addGrid(als.rank, [10, 15]) \
            .addGrid(als.maxIter, [10, 20]) \
            .addGrid(als.regParam, [0.1, 1.0]) \
            .build()

# Define evaluator as RMSE
evaluator = RegressionEvaluator(metricName = "rmse", 
                                labelCol = "rating", 
                                predictionCol = "prediction")
# Print length of evaluator
print ("Num models to be tested: ", len(param_grid))

# Build multiple models using TrainValidationSplit
tvs = TrainValidationSplit(estimator = als, 
                            estimatorParamMaps = param_grid, 
                            evaluator = evaluator, 
                            trainRatio=0.8)

# Run TrainValidationSplit, and choose the best set of parameters.
tvs_model = tvs.fit(training)

%md
### Out of the 8 models created with different parameter combinations, the best model RMSE is as follows:

msg.data: Out of the 8 models created with different parameter combinations, the best model RMSE is as follows:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Make predictions on test data. model is the model with combination of parameters
# that performed best.
model = tvs_model.bestModel
predictions = model.transform(test)
evaluator = RegressionEvaluator(metricName="rmse", labelCol="rating",
                                predictionCol="prediction")
rmse = evaluator.evaluate(predictions)
print("Root-mean-square error = " + str(rmse))

%md
### Best Root-mean-square error obtained: 0.898

%pyspark
# Best Params for the model:

best_rank = model.rank
best_max_ter = (model._java_obj.parent().getMaxIter())
best_reg_param =  (model._java_obj.parent().getRegParam()) 

print("Best Params: \nRank: {}, maxIter: {}, regParam: {}".format(best_rank, best_max_ter, best_reg_param))

%md
# Q4. Using the recommendation engine based on the best RMSE obtained,

msg.data: Q4. Using the recommendation engine based on the best RMSE obtained,

%md
### a)	What are the top 5 book title recommendations made for each user?

msg.data: a) What are the top 5 book title recommendations made for each user?

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Generate top 5 book recommendations for each user
userRecs = model.recommendForAllUsers(5)
print("Raw recommendation Book IDs for each user:")
userRecs.show(100, truncate = False)

%pyspark
# Fetch first 100 users and register a temporary table
userRecs.limit(100).registerTempTable("reccomendation_temp")
clean_recs = spark.sql("""SELECT user_id,
                            user_rec.book_id AS book_id,
                            user_rec.rating AS prediction
                        FROM reccomendation_temp
                        LATERAL VIEW explode(recommendations) exploded_table AS user_rec""")

%pyspark
# Fetching book titles

fields= ["user_id", "title"]
a = clean_recs.alias("a")
b = books_df.alias("b")

# Join with book df to get book information
print("User Id and top 5 book title recommendations (we have 5 titles for each user):")
a.join(b, col('a.book_id') == col('b.id'), how="left").drop(b["book_id"]).select(fields).show(500, truncate = False)

paragraphs.text:
%md
### b)	What are the top 5 user recommendation made for each book title?

msg.data: b) What are the top 5 user recommendation made for each book title?

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Generate top 5 user recommendations for each book
bookRecs = model.recommendForAllItems(5)
print("Raw recommendation user IDs for each book ID:")
bookRecs.show(10, truncate = False)

%pyspark
# Fetch first 100 users and register a temporary table
bookRecs.limit(100).registerTempTable("reccomendation_temp")
clean_recs = spark.sql("""SELECT book_id,
                            book_rec.user_id AS user_id
                        FROM reccomendation_temp
                        LATERAL VIEW explode(recommendations) exploded_table AS book_rec""")

%md
#### Since we do not have user information provided hence, we can only show top 5 recommended user IDs for each book title.

msg.data: Since we do not have user information provided hence, we can only show top 5 recommended user IDs for each book title.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Fetching book titles

fields= ["book_id", "title", "user_id"]
a = clean_recs.alias("a")
b = books_df.alias("b")

# Join with book df to get book information
print("Book title and top 5 user ID recommendations (we have 5 user IDs for each book):")
a.join(b, col('a.book_id') == col('b.id'), how="left").drop(b["book_id"]).select(fields).show(500, truncate = False)

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Q5. For user 1, what are the book titles recommendations made by your model actually appear in the users “to read” list? What is your conclusion from the same?

msg.data: Q5. For user 1, what are the book titles recommendations made by your model actually appear in the users “to read” list? What is your conclusion from the same?

paragraphs.text:
%md
### User 1's to-read list is as follows:

msg.data: User 1’s to-read list is as follows:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
fields= ["authors", "title", "original_publication_year", "average_rating"]
a = to_read_df.alias("a")
b = books_df.alias("b")

# Join with book df to get book information
a.filter(a.user_id==1).join(b, col('a.book_id') == col('b.id'), how="left").drop(b["book_id"]).select(fields).show(truncate = False)

%md
### Our top 5 recommendations of books for User 1 is as follows:

msg.data: Our top 5 recommendations of books for User 1 is as follows:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Create a temporary table for user 1 data
userRecs.filter(userRecs.user_id==1).registerTempTable("reccomendation_temp")
clean_recs = spark.sql("""SELECT user_id,
                            user_rec.book_id AS book_id,
                            user_rec.rating AS prediction
                        FROM reccomendation_temp
                        LATERAL VIEW explode(recommendations) exploded_table AS user_rec""")

%pyspark
fields= ["authors", "title", "original_publication_year", "average_rating"]
a = clean_recs.alias("a")
b = books_df.alias("b")

# Join with book df to get book information
a.filter(a.user_id==1).join(b, col('a.book_id') == col('b.id'), how="left").drop(b["book_id"]).select(fields).show(truncate = False)

%md
### Conclusion:

#### As we can see that our recommended books don't exactly match with the user's to-read list.
#### But the genres are quite similar and hence, they will be of interest to the user. This is a property of colaborative filtering algorithms where, the recommendations are based on what similar users are reading; this in turn helps users find new content to read and is desirable. More so, all the recommendations are highly rated ensuring quality recommendations.

msg.data:
Conclusion:

As we can see that our recommended books don’t exactly match with the user’s to-read list.

But the genres are quite similar and hence, they will be of interest to the user. This is a property of colaborative filtering algorithms where, the recommendations are based on what similar users are reading; this in turn helps users find new content to read and is desirable. More so, all the recommendations are highly rated ensuring quality recommendations.
